title: [Self-directed] Practical Optimization of Socio-Environmental Management Through Dissolved Oxygen (DO) Control in Wastewater Treatment Processes

context.prior_knowledge: Basic understanding of wastewater treatment processes, foundational control systems concepts, basic comprehension of environmental regulations and sustainability principles, foundational awareness of social responsibility and civic participation
context.additional_context: A practice-oriented course for environmental facility managers/educators in corporations, aiming for instructional design that simultaneously considers environmental safety and economic efficiency in industrial settings. Learners cultivate the ability to integrate social responsibility with technical solutions and learn how to establish collaborative systems with local communities.

learning_goals: Learners will explain the scientific principles of dissolved oxygen (DO) control in wastewater treatment processes and its environmental management significance from a social responsibility perspective.

Learners will understand the application principles of fuzzy logic and online Q-learning-based intelligent control methods, analyze them from a socio-technical system perspective, and link them to citizen participation.

Learners analyze three DO (Dissolved Oxygen) concentration simulation cases within one week, prepare a report meeting at least two control performance evaluation metrics (accuracy ±5%, response time ≤30 seconds), propose sustainable environmental management strategies based on results, and explore community collaboration methods.
difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
